transcript:
Patient: This has been a lot to take in, but I'm starting to see how my thoughts and beliefs are connected to my feelings and behaviors. It's not easy to challenge these beliefs, but I'm willing to keep trying.

Therapist: You're doing great, Maria. It takes courage to examine our thoughts and beliefs, especially when they're deeply ingrained. Remember, change is a process, and it's okay to take it one step at a time. I'm here to support you every step of the way.

Let's practice challenging one of your negative thoughts using the evidence-gathering technique we discussed earlier. Can you think of a recent situation where you had a self-critical thought?

Patient: Yes, just the other day, I was struggling to keep up with my coursework, and I started thinking, "I'm not smart enough to get my PhD. I'm going to fail."

Therapist: Okay, let's write that down as your automatic thought. Now, let's look at the evidence for and against this thought. What evidence do you have that supports the idea that you're not smart enough to get your PhD?

Patient: Well, I've been struggling to understand some of the concepts in my classes, and I feel like I'm falling behind. I also compare myself to my classmates, and they seem to be doing better than I am.

Therapist: I understand how that can be discouraging. Now, let's look at the evidence against this thought. What evidence do you have that contradicts the idea that you're not smart enough to get your PhD?

Patient: I guess I have to remember that I was accepted into the program because of my academic achievements and potential. I've also had moments where I've contributed valuable insights in class discussions, and my professors have given me positive feedback on my work.

Therapist: That's great evidence to consider. It shows that you have the intelligence and skills to succeed in your program, even if you're facing challenges right now. Another way to challenge this thought is to consider alternative explanations for the situation. What might be another reason why you're struggling with your coursework, besides not being smart enough?

Patient: It could be that I'm adjusting to a new learning environment and the demands of graduate-level work. It's also possible that I'm putting too much pressure on myself to be perfect, and that's causing me to feel overwhelmed and doubt myself.

Therapist: Those are both valid points. Adjusting to a new learning environment can be challenging, and putting too much pressure on yourself can lead to self-doubt and anxiety. What might be a more balanced and compassionate way to view this situation?

Patient: I could remind myself that it's normal to face challenges and have moments of self-doubt, but that doesn't mean I'm not capable of succeeding. I can also try to focus on my progress and the things I'm doing well, instead of comparing myself to others.

Therapist: That's a great way to reframe the situation. By acknowledging the challenges you're facing and focusing on your progress and strengths, you can develop a more balanced and compassionate view of yourself and your abilities. Remember, you don't have to be perfect to be successful. It's okay to struggle and make mistakes along the way. That's part of the learning process.

Patient: Thank you, Nova. That's a good reminder. I'll try to be more mindful of my self-talk and practice challenging my negative thoughts when they come up.

Therapist: You're welcome, Maria. Challenging negative thoughts takes practice, but the more you do it, the easier it becomes. I'm proud of the progress you're making, and I'm confident that you have the skills and resilience to overcome the challenges you're facing.
